Award.AwardTitle: Topics in anisotropic mesh adaptation and application to anisotropic diffusion problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator will study anisotropic mesh adaptation for use in the numerical solution of partialdifferential equations. The studies will be based on a so-called M-uniform mesh approach of anisotropic mesh adaptation where any nonuniform mesh is generated as a uniform one in the metric specified by a tensor. Success has been made with the approach in facilitating a better understanding of existing algorithms and in developing new methods. A specific application area is the numerical solution of anisotropic diffusion problems. New mesh conditions and metric tensors for use in mesh generation have been developed with the approach so that finite element approximations to a class of anisotropic diffusion problems satisfy a discrete maximum principle and exhibit no spurious oscillations and artifacts. The research topics will include the extension of the existing theory to three dimensional problems and time dependent problems and the development of a posteriori anisotropic error estimates and metric tensors.

The project is concerned with the development of efficient and reliable methods for the numerical solution of anisotropic diffusion problems and other problems exhibiting anisotropic features. Those problems arise from several application areas including plasma physics (fusion experiments and astrophysics), groundwater contamination modeling, petroleum reservoir simulation, image processing, and global climate simulation that are crucial to our national's economy, environment, and security. Unfortunately, standard numerical methods often produce spurious oscillations and artifacts and introduce excessive numerical dissipation in the numerical solution due to the highly anisotropy and heterogeneous nature of diffusion in those problems. In this project, anisotropic mesh adaptation will be employed to overcome these difficulties. It is a type of mesh adaptation that allows the size, shape, and orientation of mesh elements to change throughout the physical domain. The investigator has demonstrated in his work that a linear finite element solution can be made to satisfy the maximum principle and thus contains no spurious oscillations when a properly chosen anisotropic mesh is used. In-depth studies of anisotropic mesh adaptation will be carried out along this line in the project. Maximum-principle preserving schemes will be developed for time dependent problems and three dimensional problems and their application to anisotropic diffusion problems will be investigated. The studies will lead to a better understanding of anisotropic mesh adaptation and provide a useful tool for the numerical simulation of application problems, including anisotropic diffusion problems which have many important applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award supported the studies of the efficient and reliable numerical solution of anisotropic diffusion problems and other problems exhibiting anisotropic behavior. Those problems arise from various fields of science and engineering including plasma physics, groundwater contamination modeling, petroleum reservoir simulation, image processing, and global climate simulation that are crucial to our national’s economy, environment, and security. The research has focused on adaptive mesh and structure preserving computation of those problems. Hessian recovery has been commonly employed to obtain magnitude and directional information of the solution error in anisotropic mesh adaptation of those problems but is known to be nonconvergent as the mesh is refined. Studies have been carried out to understand why and how it works and thus provide a mathematical justification for its use in mesh adaptation. Another issue is the conditioning of algebraic systems resulting from the spatial discretization of the problems on anisotropic meshes. It plays an crucial role in the efficient solution of the algebraic systems. The conditioning of the stiffness and mass matrices has been studied for linear elliptic and parabolic equations on arbitrary meshes and the effects of the interplay between the mesh geometry and the diffusion matrix on the conditioning was estimated. Polygonal meshes have the advantage of being more flexible for complicated geometry than simplicial meshes.Anisotropic quality measures and an anisotropic adaptation algorithm for those meshes have been developed for use in the numerical solution of partial differential equations. Furthermore, a simple and geometric discretization has been discovered for the variational and moving mesh approaches of anisotropic mesh adaptation, which is expected to facilitate the development of more efficient implementations of those methods. Numerical solution of anisotropic diffusion problems and anisotropic eigenvalue problems was investigated. Mesh conditions were obtained for the finite element and the weak Galerkin approximations of those problems to preserve structures such as the maximum principle, solution nonnegativity, and principal eigenvalue theory. The results are of theoretical and practical importance to ensure that the computed solution is physically meaningful. Motivated by these investigations, an anisotropic eigenvalue model was successfully applied to segmentation in image processing.


The award also supported other education and research activities. Five graduate students and two postdoctoral fellows were involved in the research project and received extensive trainings to improve their research capabilities and gain useful skills for their career development. Education activities also include teaching a graduate level course at the 2011 Atlantic Association for Research in Mathematical Sciences Summer School and giving a short course at the International Workshop on Recent Developments in Adaptive Methods for PDEs. Each of them attracted about thirty graduate students and junior researchers. Other research activities include the organization of two international conferences and several minisymposia at international conferences. The award also facilitated a collaboration with aerospace engineers to develop the guidance for multi-agent fixed-wing aircraft using moving mesh methods.
